name: df-or
comment: Define disjunction (logical "or"). Definition of [Margaris] p. 49. When the left operand, right operand, or both are true, the result is true; when both sides are false, the result is false. For example, it is true that ` ( 2 = 3 \/ 4 = 4 ) ` ( ~ ex-or ). After we define the constant true ` T. ` ( ~ df-tru ) and the constant false ` F. ` ( ~ df-fal ), we will be able to prove these truth table values: ` ( ( T. \/ T. ) <-> T. ) ` ( ~ truortru ), ` ( ( T. \/ F. ) <-> T. ) ` ( ~ truorfal ), ` ( ( F. \/ T. ) <-> T. ) ` ( ~ falortru ), and ` ( ( F. \/ F. ) <-> F. ) ` ( ~ falorfal ). Contrast with ` /\ ` ( ~ df-an ), ` -> ` ( ~ wi ), ` -/\ ` ( ~ df-nan ), and ` \/_ ` ( ~ df-xor ). (Contributed by NM, 27-Dec-1992.)
